contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Ennichi''' ({{Nihongo2|縁日}}; lit. "related day") is a day believed to have a special relation ([[Wikt:縁#Japanese|en]]) with a particular Japanese deity. Often, it is a day when a deity is believed to have been born or left the world. In [[Shinto]], this day is encouraged to be embraced as it is in the "four affirmations" of their religious code. Japanese people generally think that visiting a temple or a shrine on these holy days related to [[Kami]] and/or [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] will bring greater fortunes than on regular days. Therefore, temples and shrines often hold festivals. At such events, there are generally a large number of food stalls selling [[Japanese cuisine|Japanese food]] such as ''[[takoyaki]]'', ''[[okonomiyaki]]'', grilled corn, and [[candy floss]].
